title: Cambridge graduate drowned in family pool while celebrating brother's birthday
text:

A young Cambridge graduate drowned in his family's swimming pool at his younger brother's birthday party, an inquest heard.

Friends pulled Dominic Hamlyn from the pool and his father, world-famous neurosurgeon Peter Hamlyn, gave him mouth-to-mouth in a bid to save him.

Dominic, 24, had just given a 15 minute speech to guests toasting his brother before going for a swim with his friends.

Paramedics were called to the house near Canterbury, Kent, in the early hours of July 28 when it became clear that Dominic was unresponsive, an inquest heard.

Finding a weak pulse, they took him to William Harvey Hospital, where he died later that evening.

(Image: Facebook)

A post-mortem gave the cause of death as multiple organ failure, with acute respiratory distress syndrome and drowning named as contributing factors.

Dominic's devastated father described his son a "beautiful, beautiful boy".

He said: "Why did he die? He was a superb athlete competing in both rugby and rowing at Cambridge.

"We are broken. If Dominic is to be remembered, it is as a hero and one of the world's helpers."

(Image: Facebook)

After studying at The King's School, Dominic went on to study at University College London, graduating with a first class degree in science and engineering in 2017.

The accomplished scholar then studied for a Master of Philosophy at Cambridge's prestigious Judge Business School.

Outside of his studies, Dominic helped found an online retail business, could speak Spanish and was a rugby player.

He represented UCL's 1st XV for three years, and was elected as the university's sports officer in his final year.

In 2014, he ran the London Marathon in aid of The Brain & Spine Foundation - for which he managed to raise almost £5,700.

The full inquest into Dominic's death was adjourned to take place at Canterbury Magistrates' Court on December 4.
description: Dominic Hamlyn's father, world-famous neurosurgeon Peter Hamlyn, gave him mouth-to-mouth after he was pulled from the swimming pool at his family's house near Canterbury, Kent
